encounters.details: Patient presents for his annual physical. Reports occasional headaches.
encounters.comparison: Blood pressure was borderline elevated at last year's check-up.
encounters.findings: Blood pressure is consistently elevated at 145/95 mmHg. Physical exam is otherwise unremarkable.
encounters.impression: Stage 1 Hypertension. Counseled on lifestyle modifications including diet and exercise. To start on Lisinopril 10mg daily.

encounters.details: Follow-up visit to monitor blood pressure after starting medication.
encounters.comparison: Previous blood pressure was 145/95 mmHg.
encounters.findings: Patient reports good adherence to medication. Blood pressure is now 130/85 mmHg.
encounters.impression: Blood pressure is well-controlled on Lisinopril. Continue current dosage and follow up in 6 months.

encounters.details: Patient complains of facial pain, headache, and nasal congestion for the past week.
encounters.comparison: No history of chronic sinus issues.
encounters.findings: Tenderness over maxillary sinuses. Nasal endoscopy shows purulent discharge.
encounters.impression: Acute Bacterial Sinusitis. Prescribed a 10-day course of Amoxicillin.

encounters.details: Patient referred for evaluation of recurrent, debilitating headaches preceded by visual disturbances.
encounters.comparison: Previously diagnosed with tension headaches.
encounters.findings: Neurological examination is normal. Patient's description of symptoms is classic for migraine with aura.
encounters.impression: Migraine with aura. Started on preventative medication (Topiramate) and provided with a rescue medication (Sumatriptan).

encounters.details: Follow-up to assess response to new migraine regimen.
encounters.comparison: Patient was experiencing 3-4 migraines per month.
encounters.findings: Patient reports a significant reduction in migraine frequency to 1 per month. Rescue medication is effective.
encounters.impression: Good response to treatment. Continue current medication and follow up as needed.

encounters.details: Patient presented to the ER after twisting her ankle while hiking.
encounters.comparison: No prior significant injuries to the left ankle.
encounters.findings: Swelling and ecchymosis over the lateral aspect of the left ankle. X-ray is negative for fracture.
encounters.impression: Moderate ankle sprain. Advised RICE protocol and provided with an ankle brace.

encounters.details: Follow-up for ankle sprain.
encounters.comparison: Significant swelling and pain at the time of injury.
encounters.findings: Swelling has decreased, and range of motion is improving. Patient is able to bear some weight.
encounters.impression: Healing well. Referred to physical therapy to aid in recovery.

encounters.details: Annual physical examination. Patient is asymptomatic.
encounters.comparison: Lipid panel from two years ago was borderline high.
encounters.findings: Lab results show elevated LDL cholesterol at 165 mg/dL.
encounters.impression: Hyperlipidemia. Recommended dietary changes and a follow-up lipid panel in 3 months.

encounters.details: Follow-up to re-evaluate lipid levels after a trial of lifestyle modification.
encounters.comparison: Previous LDL was 165 mg/dL.
encounters.findings: Repeat lipid panel shows LDL at 150 mg/dL. Modest improvement.
encounters.impression: Insufficient response to diet and exercise. Started on Atorvastatin 20mg daily.

encounters.details: Follow-up to assess response to statin therapy.
encounters.comparison: LDL was 150 mg/dL prior to starting medication.
encounters.findings: LDL cholesterol is now 95 mg/dL. Patient tolerating medication well.
encounters.impression: Excellent response to Atorvastatin. Continue current dosage.

encounters.details: Patient complains of urinary frequency and nocturia.
encounters.comparison: No previous urological issues.
encounters.findings: Digital rectal exam reveals an enlarged, non-tender prostate. PSA level is within the normal range.
encounters.impression: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH). Started on Tamsulosin to improve urinary symptoms.

encounters.details: Follow-up on BPH management.
encounters.comparison: Patient had significant urinary frequency and nocturia.
encounters.findings: Patient reports a marked improvement in urinary flow and a decrease in nighttime awakenings.
encounters.impression: Symptoms are well-managed on Tamsulosin. Continue current therapy.

encounters.details: Annual check-up. Patient reports increased thirst and fatigue.
encounters.comparison: Last year's fasting blood sugar was in the pre-diabetic range.
encounters.findings: Fasting blood glucose is 150 mg/dL, and HbA1c is 7.5%.
encounters.impression: New diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. Started on Metformin and referred to a diabetes educator.

encounters.details: Follow-up to monitor glycemic control.
encounters.comparison: HbA1c was 7.5% at the time of diagnosis.
encounters.findings: Patient has been monitoring her blood sugar and has made dietary changes. HbA1c is now 6.8%.
encounters.impression: Good initial response to treatment. Continue Metformin and lifestyle changes.

encounters.details: Patient complains of chronic pain and stiffness in both knees.
encounters.comparison: Pain has been progressively worsening over the past year.
encounters.findings: X-rays of the knees show moderate joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation.
encounters.impression: Bilateral Osteoarthritis of the knees. Recommended physical therapy and scheduled for corticosteroid injections.

encounters.details: Patient presents with a severe sore throat, fever, and profound fatigue for the past week.
encounters.comparison: No recent significant illnesses.
encounters.findings: Physical exam reveals exudative pharyngitis and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Monospot test is positive.
encounters.impression: Infectious Mononucleosis. Advised rest, hydration, and avoidance of contact sports.

encounters.details: Follow-up for mononucleosis.
encounters.comparison: Patient had significant fatigue and sore throat.
encounters.findings: Sore throat has resolved, but fatigue persists. Spleen is no longer enlarged.
encounters.impression: Recovering from mononucleosis as expected. Cleared for a gradual return to activities.

encounters.details: Pre-participation physical for the upcoming football season.
encounters.comparison: History of mononucleosis but has fully recovered.
encounters.findings: Physical examination is completely normal. All systems are within expected limits.
encounters.impression: Cleared for full sports participation without restrictions.

encounters.details: Patient sustained a blow to the head during football practice and reports a headache and dizziness.
encounters.comparison: No prior history of head injuries.
encounters.findings: Neurological exam shows no focal deficits. Patient has a mild headache and some photophobia. CT of the head is negative.
encounters.impression: Mild Concussion. Placed on concussion protocol with cognitive and physical rest.

encounters.details: Patient reports feeling unusually tired and has noticed some weight gain despite no changes in diet or exercise.
encounters.comparison: Thyroid function tests were normal three years ago.
encounters.findings: TSH level is elevated at 9.2 mIU/L, and free T4 is low.
encounters.impression: Primary Hypothyroidism. Started on Levothyroxine 50 mcg daily.

encounters.details: Follow-up to check thyroid hormone levels after starting treatment.
encounters.comparison: Initial TSH was 9.2 mIU/L.
encounters.findings: Repeat TSH is 3.5 mIU/L. Patient reports a significant improvement in her energy levels.
encounters.impression: Euthyroid on current medication dose. Continue Levothyroxine 50 mcg and recheck in one year.

encounters.details: Patient complains of numbness and tingling in her right hand, particularly at night.
encounters.comparison: No prior neurological complaints.
encounters.findings: Positive Phalen's and Tinel's signs on the right wrist. Nerve conduction studies confirm carpal tunnel syndrome.
encounters.impression: Right-sided Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. Recommended wrist splinting at night and ergonomic adjustments at work.

encounters.details: Patient presents with a 24-hour history of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
encounters.comparison: No recent travel or sick contacts.
encounters.findings: Abdomen is soft with diffuse tenderness. Mild signs of dehydration are present.
encounters.impression: Acute Gastroenteritis, likely viral. Advised supportive care with oral rehydration.

encounters.details: Follow-up for gastroenteritis.
encounters.comparison: Patient was experiencing active vomiting and diarrhea.
encounters.findings: Symptoms have completely resolved. Patient is now well-hydrated.
encounters.impression: Full recovery from gastroenteritis.

encounters.details: Patient reports experiencing excessive worry, restlessness, and difficulty concentrating for the past several months.
encounters.comparison: No prior mental health diagnoses.
encounters.findings: Patient scores high on the GAD-7 screening tool. Meets the diagnostic criteria for Generalized Anxiety Disorder.
encounters.impression: Generalized Anxiety Disorder. Discussed treatment options, and the patient opted to start cognitive-behavioral therapy.

encounters.details: Follow-up to assess progress with therapy.
encounters.comparison: Patient was experiencing significant daily anxiety.
encounters.findings: Patient reports that CBT has been very helpful in managing his anxiety. He has learned several coping techniques.
encounters.impression: Positive response to therapy. Continue with CBT and follow up as needed.

encounters.details: Routine annual gynecological examination.
encounters.comparison: Previous exam a year ago was also normal.
encounters.findings: Pelvic exam is unremarkable. Pap smear results are normal.
encounters.impression: Healthy female. Recommend routine follow-up in one year.

encounters.details: Patient complains of a 3-day history of dysuria and urinary frequency.
encounters.comparison: History of occasional UTIs.
encounters.findings: Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and bacteria.
encounters.impression: Uncomplicated Cystitis. Prescribed a 3-day course of Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

encounters.details: Follow-up phone call to check on UTI symptoms.
encounters.comparison: Patient had significant dysuria and frequency.
encounters.findings: Patient reports complete resolution of symptoms after finishing the antibiotic course.
encounters.impression: Resolution of urinary tract infection.

encounters.details: Referred for evaluation of persistent fatigue and lightheadedness.
encounters.comparison: Previous complete blood count showed borderline anemia.
encounters.findings: CBC confirms microcytic anemia with a low hemoglobin and hematocrit. Iron studies show low ferritin and serum iron.
encounters.impression: Iron Deficiency Anemia, likely secondary to menorrhagia. Started on oral iron supplementation.

encounters.details: Follow-up to assess response to iron therapy.
encounters.comparison: Hemoglobin was 10.2 g/dL.
encounters.findings: Repeat CBC shows hemoglobin has improved to 11.8 g/dL. Patient reports a noticeable increase in her energy levels.
encounters.impression: Good response to iron supplementation. Continue for at least three more months to replenish iron stores.

encounters.details: Annual physical examination. No new complaints.
encounters.comparison: No significant changes in health status since his last visit.
encounters.findings: Physical exam and routine screening labs are all within normal limits.
encounters.impression: Healthy adult male. Continue with a healthy lifestyle.

encounters.details: Patient presents with sudden onset of severe left flank pain radiating to the groin, accompanied by nausea.
encounters.comparison: No prior history of kidney stones.
encounters.findings: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis reveals a 5mm calculus at the left ureterovesical junction.
encounters.impression: Obstructing nephrolithiasis. Managed with intravenous fluids and pain medication. Patient is a candidate for medical expulsive therapy.

encounters.details: Follow-up after his ER visit for a kidney stone.
encounters.comparison: Patient was in severe pain at the time of presentation.
encounters.findings: Patient reports that he passed the stone two days ago and his pain has completely resolved. A repeat kidney ultrasound is normal.
encounters.impression: Resolution of the kidney stone episode. Advised on dietary measures to prevent future stone formation.

encounters.details: Patient complains of frequent heartburn, especially after meals and when lying down.
encounters.comparison: Symptoms have become more bothersome over the last six months.
encounters.findings: Physical examination is normal. Based on the classic symptoms, a clinical diagnosis of GERD is made.
encounters.impression: GERD. Prescribed a daily proton pump inhibitor (Omeprazole) and advised on lifestyle modifications.

encounters.details: Follow-up to evaluate the effectiveness of GERD treatment.
encounters.comparison: Patient had daily heartburn.
encounters.findings: Patient reports a significant reduction in heartburn symptoms with Omeprazole.
encounters.impression: Symptoms are well-controlled. Continue the current treatment plan.

encounters.details: Patient presents with a chief complaint of stabbing pain in her right heel, which is worse with the first steps in the morning.
encounters.comparison: No prior history of foot problems.
encounters.findings: There is point tenderness over the medial calcaneal tuberosity.
encounters.impression: Plantar Fasciitis. Recommended stretching exercises, icing, and the use of supportive footwear.

encounters.details: Follow-up for plantar fasciitis.
encounters.comparison: Patient had significant heel pain.
encounters.findings: The patient has been compliant with the recommended conservative treatments and reports that her heel pain is much improved.
encounters.impression: Good response to conservative management. Continue with the current regimen.
